::: columns

::: notes

**MAS/MILS** (Minerals Availability System/Mineral Information Location System, compiled by US Bureau of Mines (former), now by USGS:
 - In Yuba/Bear/American Rivers alone, estimates that 857 million cubic yards were excavated (8x more material than was excavated in construction of Panama Canal) From W. T. Ellis Jr. U of O 1939
 - Export mining debris estim. from 1849 to 1914, 1.146 billion cubic yards deposited in SF Bay (USGS Significant Deposits Database - Long and others, 1998)
 - Immense amounts of timber required for flumes and check dams, logged over 20 miles away from site
 - Over a thirty-year period, the Comstock Lode consumed more than 800 million feet of lumber (Rohe, Randall. “Man and the Land: Mining’s Impact in the Far West.” Arizona and the West (1986): 299-388) 

:::

::: {.columns .pv4}
::: {.column .pr4 width="50%" .incremental}

 - Projected mean extinction rates in freshwater organisms 5x greater than terrestrial (Ricciardi & Rasmussen 1999)

## Dammed Rivers {.smaller background-image="../img/dams_in_CA.png" background-size="49%" background-position="right" background-color="#001B44"}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column .pr2 width="45%" .incremental}

 - Over 1,400 large dams (NID 2007)
 - CA hydropower is ~15% of energy supply (Hall 2006)
 - Residential energy demands expected to increase by 24% by 2035 (US EIA 2010)
 - Majority of dams are for irrigation (47%), water supply (23%), and hydroelectric (14%)

:::
:::


::: footer
Unnatural History: Regulation
:::

::: notes

Majority (84%) of dams are for: 
 - 47% Irrigation (n=709) 
 - 23% Water supply (n=342) 
 - 14% Hydroelectric (n=207)
 
 Electricity demand up >>> Due to growth in population and continued population shifts to warmer regions with greater cooling requirements (US EIA, Annual Energy Outlook 2010).  
 Hydroelectric power generation comprises over half of all renewable energy generation in California (California Energy Commission 2010. Majority of Dams are owned by Private entities (658), Public Utilities (308), then Local Govt (324), Federal (151), and State (53) (NID: National Inventory of Dams, 2007)

:::

## Flow Seasonality

 > Species life histories are finely tuned to capitalize on specialized [**temporal**]{.f1 .black} niches associated with climatic variability (Chesson 2000, Chase 2011)

::: {.incremental}

 - [**Seasonality**]{.orange} is measure of occurrence of distinct within-year conditions or events

 - [**Predictability**]{.blue} is the regularity of recurrence annually

:::


::: footer
Unnatural History: Regulation
:::
::: notes
Species life histories are finely tuned to capitalize on specialized temporal niches associated with climatic variability (Chesson 2000, Chase 2011). 

“Seasonality is the occurrence of certain obvious biotic and abiotic events or groups of events within a definite limited period or periods of the astronomic (solar, calendar) year.” Essentially, this represents the degree to which within-year conditions are distinct. Lieth (1974:5)

“Predictability is the regularity of recurrence of the within cycle (e.g., annual) distribution of events across multiple cycles”
:::
